Section 102 prohibits trafficking in counterfeit components by amending Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The amendment specifies penalties for knowingly trafficking in counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to various types of works, including phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. Penalties include fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. The act allows copyright owners to bring civil actions in court for violations, granting the court the discretion to issue injunctions and order the impounding of any related equipment or materials. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" allows courts to impound articles involved in violations, award attorney fees, actual damages, and profits to the injured party. The injured party can recover actual damages and profits attributable to the violation. The court calculates actual damages by multiplying the actual damages suffered by the injured party with any profits of the violator not included in the calculation. The court calculates actual damages by multiplying the value of counterfeit items with the number of those items. The 'value' is based on the retail value of authorized products. The court may award statutory damages ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 for each violation of copyright infringement, instead of actual damages and profits. The court may award statutory damages up to $25,000 for each violation of copyright infringement. Subsequent violations may result in damages being tripled. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 2318 regarding trafficking in counterfeit labels. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability or limitations under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, or fair use under section 107 of Title 17. It also specifies that the amendments do not apply to electronic transmissions of certain documents or packaging under Title 18, United States Code. The fair use provision under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code, allows for the use of genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, labeling components, or documentation described in Title 18, United States Code. TITLE II--FRAUDULENT ONLINE IDENTITY SANCTIONS

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title may be cited as the "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act".

SEC. 202. AMENDMENT TO TRADEMARK ACT OF 1946.

Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided in connection with a domain name violation. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement in cases where false contact information is knowingly provided to a domain name registrar. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as per the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. (a) Sentencing Enhancement.--Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to double the maximum imprisonment for a felony offense if the defendant knowingly falsely registered a domain name and used it in the course of the offense. The term 'falsely registers' means registering in a way that prevents identification or contact with the person who registers. The term 'domain name' is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure harsh penalties for felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information. Sentencing enhancements will be provided for those convicted of providing false contact information to domain name authorities. The subsection defines the term "domain name" as per the Trademark Act of 1946. It pertains to penalties for using false contact information when registering a domain name. SEC. 205. CONSTRUCTION. This section clarifies that the rights of free speech and press are not affected by the registration or use of domain names. It also emphasizes that courts have discretion in determining damages, relief, and terms of imprisonment for intellectual property rights infringement. TITLE III--COURTS includes amendments for additional court locations in Colorado and Northern District of New York. Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code, amended to include "Plattsburgh" after "Malone."
